Flash plugin was not working and after ticking all possible options in chrome://settings, chrome://flags, chrome://components, and chrome://plugins, I still was not able to make it work. Okay, so even html5 video was not working for me and that turned out to be video driver issue (!). As for PepperFlash. I had to rename directory C:\Users\john\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\PepperFlash to something else so that I can a fresh copy downloaded via chrome://components.

So with the absence of NPAPI, some plugins that took advantage of flash plugin's security hole is gone. For me I used Enounce's myspeed to speed up the playback speed of flash videos.

Fortunately there is a chrome plugin that could control the playback speed of HTML5 videos, which is the new standard on the web anyway. It would have been nice if the plugin for forcing html5 also work so that the chrome web browser tries html5 before falling back to flash. But this is not working for me. I chose to disable flash player altogether since I don't really use it.

NPAPI is also going to get ditched by Firefox and fortunately there is addon to control the playback speed of html5 vidoe here.

entry.content:
The following assumes that you have encrypted data, which you should!

NAS

Synology owns in this market. There are free alternatives like XPenology or FreeNAS, but many warned about the lack of security, reliability, and simplicity in use. Pros:

  • features: there are tones of features you can take advantage of: RAID, encryption, and third party backup solution compatibility
  • simplicity: you set it once and let it do its job

Cons:

  • cost: a good brand NAS like Synology will cost you at least $200 for an entry-level 2-bay NAS without disks

RAID enabled enclosure

Not really a backup strategy, but the idea of running RAID1 on my external hard drive seemed pretty cool... until I read people's experiences.

Pros:

  • cost: usually the hard drives come bundled up and they are not such a bad price. The enclosure alone will cost about $75.
  • simplicity: if you want just encryption and RAID1, there is not really any setup you need to do.

Cons: - recovery: the option is limited for hardware-encrypted drives in case there is a failure.

Online backup

I think Crashplan is the most popular option with its attractive pricing option and reliability.

Pros:

  • reliability: most backup services uses Amazon's infrastructure or their own propriety infrastructure that provides a reliable redundancy.

Cons:

  • cost: you will pay just about buying new drives every four years or so. Which is not terribly bad but the cost can be very costly if you try to recover data via physical copy of the disk.
  • Time: Uploading/Downloading everything will take forever.
  • privacy: You have your data in the cloud and despite the encryption there is always some privacy concern. If you encrypt your data before uploading, you lose the versioning features of the service.

Hard drive duplicator

This is popular for some reason, but I found it pretty much unusable for my case.

Pros:

  • easy: just plug in the drive and click "start"
  • predictability: sector-by-sector copy will take the same time every time

Cons:

  • disk size: the source drive has to be smaller than the destination drive. This may end up costing you more money if you want to upgrade the size of the disk.
  • connectivity: most external drives these days have USB connector bolted on instead of SATA connectors. And there is no USB to SATA connector available in the market. You will have to stick with internal hard drives.
  • not interruptible: The operation cannot be interrupted in between.
  • interoperability: the hard drives will end up with the same signature so they both cannot be connected at the same time.
  • time-consuming: the copy happens for the entire drive regardless of the data you used, so the operation could take a half-day, which, for me was unacceptable.

Manual

Use a computer to mount decrypted drives before syncing them via robocopy or rsync

Pros:

  • flexible: you can do whatever you want

Cons:

  • complicated: you need to decrypt first
  • CPU intensive: decrypting the drive and copying requires a dedicated computer
  • Sync schedule gaps: between the times you actually sync the drives, there is a chance that there is a drive failure and you lose some data. This happened to me.

entry.content:
I just bought Synology DS215j. It was the best for the buck if I just ditch the video decoding

Reason for a local backup

Simple. I make a backup of my partition so that in case of theft, loss of my device, or a hard drive failure, I could get back my working system setup immediately. The size of these backups are pretty large and I don't want to risk these backups not being uploaded completely to the off-site. Since my primary machine is a laptop and the availability of high-speed internet is not always guaranteed, I want to a backup solution that is local and fast.

Router with USB support

Modern day routers have CPUs that are comparable to a dedicated NAS server and the best ones could maximize the external hard drives' throughput. But don't fall into the temptation. At best you will have a cheap NAS solution that will be seriously limited compared to a dedicated solution.

Here are a few things that a dedicated NAS wins on top of my head:

  • encryption: There isn't any for DD-WRT or Tomato
  • RAID: Once again, there isn't any for DD-WRT. You could possible pair the router with RAID external closure, but then it will have its own limitation. If there is a drive failure, you cannot access the remaining working drive with another enclosure, because the encryption is hardware-based and not software-based
  • synchronization with existing cloud solutions: you can install Crashplan's headless client or Dropbox module to make your workflow better, or Amazon Glazier backup for a cheap off-site backup.
  • media support: a true media solution does not really exist in the free solution
  • accessibility: you will have nice GUI on your web browser and your phone
  • easy setup and update: enough said

Mac Mini

Didn't want to leave the Apple folks out of the discussion and this post compares the pros/cons very well.

2-bay vs 4-bay

cantbelieveitsbacon at reddit summarizes it well for me.

  • 2 bay systems are simpler and easier to keep consistent across the board. When things fail (and they will) you will be happy that things that need fixing are simple and consistent.
  • RAID 1 reliabilty > RAID 5 reliability
  • RAID 1 recovery is trivial. RAID 5 recovery is tricky due to striping.
  • Drive replication for offsite storage is trivial on a 2-bay NAS: plug a new drive until it syncs, remove it, ship offsite. Can't do that with striped drives.
  • NAS hardware generations improve faster than we can fill up drives.
  • HDD cost falls faster than the HDD failure rate. It's more cost-effective to buy pairs of ever-better drives on an "as needed" basis.
  • RAID 1 RW throughput is sufficient for our purpose.

XPenology

This was a tempting for me. Hacking nature inside of me wanted to just tinker with a new box a bit. But I ultimately decided it is not worth my time and I think the cost benefit really kicks in when I build a large NAS with a lot of hard drives to take advantage of a higher order RAID configuration and need CPU intensive tasks like transcoding videos. But if your use case is simple and your needs are modest, going with Synology is better. Otherwise, your NAS will end up being overkill or too costly for the actual usage. For example, I could turn a laptop into a NAS by replacing the optical drive bay with additional 2.5 hard drive, but then my NAS will not saturate the quad core or the 8GB RAM it has. I would much rather turn it into a hackintosh than a NAS.

Which drives?

I just went with two WD Red Non-Pro drives from eBay for less than $70 each. For about the same price you can snag Hitach's 3TB refurbished drives that have better reliability rates and that will be my choice next time. I just didn't research enough before I bought the drives. I will probably still benefit from these low wattage and quiet drives. If I really want to be cost efficient though, I will get green drives and run wdiddle3 to turn off idle spin-down and use them. Western Digital does too much marketing. It is working, though, because it fooled me.

Hard drive speeds

This depends on your needs, but slower drives are cheaper, quieter, and more reliable than the faster drives. I think I lean towards slower speed drives because I tend to work with smaller file sizes on my local machine and I prefer quietness of the device.

Join mp4 videos in minutes with MP4Joiner

Mp4Joiner is the best program for joining two MP4 files together. Most of the camcorders and cell phones have file size limited to 4GB which translates to approximately 33 minutes for 1080p videos. If you try to merge two videos together with Sony Vegas or Adobe Premiere Pro, they re-render the entire video, taking more than four hours(!). But this program merely slice the metadata and merge the video together, taking less than 10 minutes. You can do the same thing with ffmpeg, but I like the optino of dragging and seeing the metadata on the application.

Splitting mp4 videos

This time I need to use ffmpeg. The vcodec and acodec options let me split the video file without re-encoding them, so that the operation will be done in minutes. ffmpeg.exe -i %userprofile%\Desktop\20150213.mp4 -vcodec copy -acodec copy -ss 00:00:00 -t 00:37:21 cut.mp4

Converting mp4 to mp3 with ffmpeg

ffmpeg is an amazing open source tool for any type of media conversion, but be aware that not all ffmpegs are compiled the same. I am using Windows Command Prompt.

"C:\ffmpeg\bin\ffmpeg.exe" -i C:\Users\john\Desktop\20140720.mp4 -vn -b:a 128k -c:a libmp3lame 20140720.mp3

Rotating mp4 180 degree

Sometimes I record a video with my phone in a "wrong" orientation and end up having flipped video. This undoes it, but it took quite a bit of time on my laptop:

ffpmeg

Burning Images (Audio, ISO, etc)

[ImgBurn](http://www.imgburn.com/index.php?act=download)
I recently found out that À

Mounting ISOs

[DAEMONTools](http://www.disk-tools.com/download/daemon)

Converting pdf to images

sudo apt-get install -y poppler-utils
# create #150dpi resolution
pdftoppm -png file.pdf prefix
# create #300dpi resolution
pdftoppm -rx 300 -ry 300 -png file.pdf prefix

find . -name "*.pdf" -exec bash -c 'cd $(dirname "{}") && pdftoppm -png $(basename "{}") $(basename "{}" .pdf)' \;

The use of double quote around braces is very important, as it will defer the brace expansion later after the find has completed. Using single quotes will expand the braces before the find executes and return current directory.

Converting ppt(x) to pdf

Unconv cannot convert ppt(x) to png directly. It can only process the first page, which is a pretty lame behavior. But in conjunction with pdftoppm or convert (from imagemagik), the job can be done.

sudo apt-get install unoconv
unoconv --export Quality=100 filename.pptx filename.pdf

entry.content:
Introduction

I do not want to root my phone because then I have to update my phone manually. And rooting my phone is the best way to kill my weekend time. I am going to have fun, but I am not going to get much done - I know because that is what I did with PDAs back in high school. So I was looking for a way to filter some Social Networking Services(SNS). I know that it is difficult to block the access completely, because at the end of the day, if I am determined, I can break anything, but some deterrences usually do the trick. I will add some apps on the bottom if you want to protect your filtering from getting disabled.

Journey

I tried several apps, and spent some time on Block It!, but not only you cannot trust this app, but it slows your phone and internet speed down unusably. I also tried AdBlock, you have to download APK because Google Play Store removed it due to security reasons, unfortunately, without rooting, you cannot setup a custom fitering. So here comes the solution FilterProxy.

FilterProxy to the rescue

The bland interface will probably raise a flag to an average user. You do need some patience to set it up. I am just going to write exact steps I took.

  • There is a ... (in vertical) at the right bottom corner. Then I press Export.
  • I copied it and saved in Dropbox.
  • I opened the file up on my computer and edit it with Vim. Vim-Surround is useful here to put '' tag around all the words. These words that you are going to block are regular expression statements. To put thing simply, if specify a word within that flag, it will block all URLs that has that word.
  • I copied my custom keywords: facebook, instagram, pinterest

  • I also copied some other keywords to mimic AdBlock's functionality. The credit goes to Baron Schwartz, the author of High Performance MySQL

    \bads\b 2o7 a1.yimg adbrite adclick adfarm adrevolver adserver adtech advert atdmt atwola banner bizrate blogads bluestreak burstnet casalemedia coremetrics doubleclick falkag fastclick feedstermedia googlesyndication hitbox httpads imiclk intellitxt js.overture kanoodle kontera mediaplex nextag pointroll qksrv rightmedia speedera statcounter tribalfusion webtrends

Changing your Network to use the FilterProxy

Please refer to the official manual for more details.

WIFI

  • "WIFI"
  • Select your network and press it until you see a pop up
  • "Modify network"
  • "Show advanced options"
  • "Proxy", set "Manual"
  • In "Proxy hostname", set "localhost"
  • In "Port", set "8000"(Default port number of FilterProxy is 8000)

Mobile

  • In "Main-Setting" Tab, push "setting"
  • "Mobile networks" -> "Access Point Names" -> {Using Access Point}
  • In "Proxy", set "localhost"
  • In "Port", set "8000"(Default port number of FilterProxy is 8000)

Extra filtering

I have not tried it, but Tim McCormack has his personal regex for filitering ads.

Filtering Profanity

Choose what you will, but using expression to filter profanity (or any sexual contents) are proned to side-effects But here are some lists if you wish:

  • http://urbanoalvarez.es/blog/2008/04/04/bad-words-list/
  • http://contentfilter.futuragts.com/phraselists/

Safelocking

If you want to lock https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.domobile.applock

sudo `vmware-uninstall-tool` would not work, saying it has been deprecated and I need to use `vmware-uninstall` but then there was no

I did:

sudo vmware-install -l 
sudo vmware-install -u Vmware... #Something I retrieve from the previous command
sduo rm -rf /etc/vmware*
sudo rm -rf /usr/lib/vmware*

Copy the VMWaterTool-9.6.tar.gz from the CDRom (via ISO image) and untar it to your local directory and install it.

entry.content:
Windows is on a downhill since the new Windows Vista and I have considered to switch to Linux full time and I almost have, but now I am getting a bit sick of going after drivers to make everything run properly. Windows 7 still provides a great user experience (in terms of productivity, at least) out of the box.

Here are few things I miss dearly: 1. device/hardware support (wifi, trackpad): I managed to get them to work, but I spent like 30 hours.

  1. Everything Search: I have improved my find skill grep skill with Linux, but I miss Everything Search because I do no thave to think so hard with it.

  2. file manager: I am not asking for Directory Opus, but even something like Total Commander is not available. Double Commander was buggy and it was not that well documented.

  3. Microsoft Office: Office Software Suite is still dominated by Microsoft. I wish there was more competition. Libre Office, quietly frankly, resembles Office XP. And for a keyboard shortcut enthusiast like me, Google Doc is not in the same list for the comparison.

  4. Adobe Suite: Adobe is the Microsoft of Multimedia Editing, enough said.

  5. backup software: backing up hot disk and restoring them easily is not the forte of Linux. My choice on Windows is Paragon.

  6. Other software: Like Google Pinyin keyboard, TeamViewer (keyboard binding is messed up with OpenBox), Regex Helper, Tax Turbo, Spotify, and VMWare Viewer. Even Dropbox crapped out on UTF-8 file name encoding at one point on Linux.

  7. Bad compatibility with i386 and amd64 packages: maybe there is a way around it, but some uses x86 version of libssl0.9.8, and the other uses x64. Maybe there is a way around it, but I miss the days when the applications I install would just work.

Auto dismount

on /etc/rc.local.shutdown

if (/usr/bin/truecrypt --text --list)
    then {
        /usr/bin/truecrypt -d
        sleep 3
    }
fi

Auto mount when plugged in

Find the USB device ID. They are 8 character identifier, separted by : where the first half is vender ID and second half is the ID of your device.

lsusb

Create a rule.The rules filename must start with two digits, plus a dash (-), and must end with .rules:

sudo vim /etc/udev/rules.d/85-my_rule.rules
ACTION=="add", SUBSYSTEM=="usb_device", SYSFS{idVendor}=="1058", SYSFS{idProduct}=="07a8", RUN+="~/Dropbox/linux/scripts/truecrypt-automount.sh"

Other useful options might be:

ACTION="remove" ENV{XAUTHORITY}="/home/user/.Xauthority": specify an environment variable ENV{DISPLAY}=":0": another example OWNER="user": specify which user the device belongs to GROUP: specify which group the device belongs to SYMLINK: create a link under /dev to correctly identify the device whenever it gets connected

Refresh udev service:

sudo /etc/init.d/udev restart

entry.content:
"Computer User Survery"

When I was a senior in college, I asked all of my professors why they chose to use Mac (except one professor who was a respected contributor in Linux world and was a Ubuntu fan). Their reasons were convenience and reliability for the most part. Well, I find my time pretty valuable too, but I am sticking with Windows and here are Why. I am biased in my article, because I never actually owned a mac, just used them from time to time.

Operating System

  • Accessibility: Window's High Contrast Mode is quite good. I like it more than Apple's inversed screen, because all icons still remain in the same color. It can be quite confusing to my brain if things do not line up correctly with its memory. Windows keep things constant with their color scheme. I use Life Dark Theme.
  • Compatibility: I do not use any DOS program, but it is certainly good to know that everything will still work in the future.

Hardware

  • Matte Screen: glossy screens strain my eyes. Here Apple has taken the priority on aesthetic bit too far.
  • TPM: hardware encryption is overlooked by many people, but it is certainly a nice option considering their your data is worth more than any hardware or software you own.
  • Compatibility: hey, I do not have to check for MAC-compatible sign whenever I buy a new accessory for my machine! That is one less headache for me.

Software

These are the few of my favorite things - Autohotkey: ~~I have spent an enormous amount of time hunting for some good snippets of scripts online. This probably will save my health in the long run from RSI. And I am sure I am going to get back the time I invested in back before this program becomes obsolete (to me). I cannot emphasize enough its usefulness. And no, AppleScript is not equivalent to Autohotkey. I use spell check and auto completions everywhere.~~ I found that there is Autohotkey Equivalent on OS X called Sikuli - Chocolately: finally a software manager that is very very good. Their repository covers about 80% of the software I use. - Directory Opus: Path Finder 6 for Mac is looking quite good, but really Dopus is still the king of all file managers. - Microsoft Office: whether you hate it or not, it is the most popular office suite. Mac and Linux (via Wine) do not work the same way as the original version in Windows. For example, format preservation when copying does not work. It is something I would get with Mac anyway. - Everything: a very popular search program that is available exclusive on Windows. It makes me wonder if I need to learn to use grep properly. - JVM: Oracle optimized its start time for Windows, Linux, and Solaris, but not for OS X.

(Supposedly) The Shortcomings of Windows:

  • Security (Virus): I never had a problem with a virus since a decade ago when I started using an Anti-Virus program. I have always used my common sense.
  • Reliability: people who bash Windows for BSOD either have not used Windows lately, they were doing something crazy, used unsupported hardware, or were just unlucky. Using tools like Process Monitor helps you to identify the problem fairly quickly.
  • Maintenance: With some batch files, your maintenance could be a breeze. Add Chocolately and CCleaner to the bunch and you are all set. Yes deleting a software compeltely could take some time with Revo Uninstaller, but I have not had to reinstall Windows 7 since I have installed it.
  • Terminal: So far Cygwin has not failed me yet. Yes, it takes a ton of time to get things to work properly, but I am getting better at straighten things out. In a way it has been a good exercise for me because in the past, I had the attitude of "Never debug a program that I didn't make" - which was obviously a wrong attitude. Now that Windows 10 supports bash natively, all the better.
  • Driver Updates: this one I have to hand it over to Apple. This is more of an annual chore for me, because it must be done manually and I forget do it unless something is broken.

Linux, other thoughts, and conclusion

I have seen many of my peers who use Mac installing Parallel so that they could stay connected with the rest of the world. Maybe it is not the same thing, but I had a similar experience when I was using Linux as my primary OS. I just want to say that Windows is more prevalent than you think.

Here is another problem. The moment you use an Apple product, you are deemed as a source of revenues by technology marketers. You have to pay premium for everything! Hardwares, apps, and even accessories! Kudos to Apple for simplifying and enhancing the purchase experience, but I prefer keep my bank statement as lean as possible by using free software on Windows (and Android). Free PC hardwares are easy to come by as well.

I do not hate Apple or Mac. I love the fact that they are around to keep Microsoft on their toes. Just from personal experience, I found Microsoft to be more productive, that is all.

Using Windows in my opinion is better than Mac. I still glance over Mac's software offering from time to time, but it is not good enough to convince me over. At very minimum, it will have to be either Cygwin community shrinking or Autohotkey being supported on Mac before I switch over. I do not see either happening any time soon. I'd like to thank Cygwin community who has kept things going, asking for Windows support all over Github, and answering questions on Stackoverflow and Super User forums.

P.S. Windows 8

Windows 8's High Contrast Mode did not work the same way as Windows 7's when I tested it, but I am hoping it will change soon. Latest Dell Latitude series E6540 (w/ Intel Haswell) was surprisingly offered with Windows 7, denoting that Enterprise world is not adapting Windows 8. Likewise I would not use their tiled interface. I never used the start button to begin with. But once again, I am sold on Windows because of the things that go with it. So unless Microsoft really screws up and people abandon Windows, I probably will not need a sequel to this article.

Since 2014

entry.content:
After following this tutorial you will have a laptop and an external monitor that changes brightness depending on the ambient brightness detected by a webcam. Requirements: a laptop with a webcam and linux OS (untested on a desktop with a webcam)

Calise

Calise takes care of ambient brightness using a webcam and this is all you really need if you do not have an external monitor.

sudo pip install pyephem
sudo apt-get install python-qt4 python-distutils-extra
cd ~/downloads/calise-*
sudo env python setup.py build
sudo env python setup.py install --install-layout=deb --prefix=/usr

You will get some errors about using Microsoft modules, ignore that.

You might also have to install following python modules, I had them installed already

sudo pip install dbus gobject2 xdg

Start by typing calise --configure and it will guide you through calibration process.

If you want to delete later, you can do the following:

sudo env python setup.py install --install-layout=deb --prefix=/usr --record touninstall.txt
cat touninstall.py | sudo xargs rm -rf

Brightness.py

Brightness.py controls the brightness of up to two monitors using xrandr underneath. I forked from lordamit and it seems as though the program has gotten pretty stable. My modification probably is not ready to serve all Brightness.py users as I only modified the scrip to control the secondary monitor (my external monitor) and let Calise take care of my primary monitor (laptop screen), but it serves me well and maybe for you too!

Here the link to the script on my github.

Autostart

I have the following lines in autostart file (I used Crunchbang OS), put these lines in an appropriate file for your OS that will be executed upon boot.

calised --capture-interval 30 &
(cd ~/Dropbox/linux/scripts && python brightness.py -c &)

The first line refreshed calise's brightness value every 30 seconds.

Don't use calise, because pm-utils tries to pause calised when going to sleep or hibernation mode. There is no pause option for calise

The research - though process behind brightness.py modification

I asked myself if the computer monitor's brightness is adjusted according to the ambient light, what is the best way to change the brightness? I thought of 3 criteria:

  1. The brightness adjustment is instantaneous / gradual
  2. Time interval is set to delay when the change occurs
  3. The brightness is leveled (like a laptop monitor, says 15 different levels) and brightness stays at (or gravitates, with gradual option from 1) at that level.

I think, from the usability point of view, option 1. gradual 2. ~10 sec time delay 3. 100 level is the best, like a Macbook monitor. Unfortunately, I found this difficult to achieve. Currently brightness.py changes brightness via xrandr and it lacks the direct hardware access. I am not sure if anybody out there who manages to change the brightness of an external monitor gradually, but even with 100 levels of brightness, I noticed some flickering. If I lower the delta of the change so that I have something like 500 or 1000 levels, the change is not noticeable, but I/O bus seems to get overloaded, resulting in slow mouse and keyboard responses.

So I settled for less. I modified brightness.py to change the monitor brightness every 2 minutes by default to any one of 16 levels set by calise. This ended up working well. calise changes my laptop brightness every 30 seconds, this lower interval is useful when I am moving around, but not so much when I have my big monitor and I am forced to be stationary. brigthness.py polls, but I think this was a simpler approach than using, say pynotify or watchdog, since I am dealing with only one file for a single integer value. CPU usage is unnoticeable.

In brightness.py there is an option to supply -o, --offset, which defaults to 20. This is to help balance the difference between a laptop screen and an external monitor. You can see the effect it has on setting the brightness level by setting the -vv --verbose option and seeing the numerator and denominator values. Without this offset, I found my external monitor to be dark.

Lastly, if you want a real challenge, you can go for OpenCV, which I attempted to use at first, but it is quite bit of work. Brightness.py

Windows - BLUntrl

If you use Windows, you are not out of luck. Many computer manufacturers include auto-bright features for Windows 8. And if you use Windows 7 and below, you can use BLUtrl The author kindly supplied a tool that hides the application from the user's view. http://www.expocenter.com/hideit/

Building BLUntrl

The above link as the binary, but because BLUntrl changes brightness too quickly, I wanted to put some threshold to prevent it from flickering. So I had to change the source code to get that job done. I really hate Visual Studio with passion, just because it does not have search box for the options, but I happened to have Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2012. The following was tested on Windows 7 x64. First Install Windows SDK Change "Configuration Properties->General->TargetName", because by default it wants to build as BLUntrl, but the project name is not set up that way. Just go with the instruction I have and rename the file back you preference later.

$(ProjectName) -> videoInputBasicDemo

Change "Configuration Properties->Linker->General->Output File" to $(OutDir)videoInputBasicDemo.exe Set "Configuration Properties->General->Target Name" to videoInputBasicDemo Add the following directory to "Configuration Properties->C/C++->General->Additional Include Directories"

C:\Program Files\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v7.1\Include

Add the following directory to "Configuration Properties->VC++ Directories->Library Directories"

C:\Program Files\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v7.1\Lib

Other Interesting Articles

http://blog.oscarliang.net/raspberry-pi-face-recognition-opencv/ https://github.com/ishanthilina/setBrightness/blob/master/src/setBrightness.py http://blog.ishans.info/2011/09/25/set-brightness-automatically-at-the-startup-in-linux/ http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16375396/changing-days-and-nights-with-pygame

Other softwares I am yet to try:

  • ScreenBright
  • ClickMonitorDDC
  • softMCCS

entry.content:
The story

Skip this section if you think your life is short.

I tried to block myself out of pornography ever since I was a teenager. My first attempt was using K9 Web Protection. I took a lot of time to filter false-positive websites, but I was not satisfied for long. I had trouble connecting to wifi on college campus and it also did not filter SSL connections properly, which meant I had unprotected Google images access. Oh my. Also I now knew Linux pretty well, so I was loose on the web. They have improved quite a bit when I tested it last month, so I recommend it if you do not want to go through the complicated steps below.

Then years of exploration began: OpenDNS, Dans-guardian, squidguard, qustodio... and even trying to lock myself out of the administrator's account! They all failed, but I must say, my efforts were not all that wasteful, as I learned about the network security and I started to think like a parent. I also discovered so many loopholes. Now I know that SOCKS Proxy and OpenVPN would pretty much render all parental control moot.

As with all computer security, there is no perfect parental control, but there is pretty good one: DD-WRT + OpenDNS + iptables. Of course, you have to hand over the password to someone, but as long as you do not know the password, you are relatively safe! It is perfect for me as of now, although I still have to work around some issues and I had to sacrifice some remote capabilities. In the worst case, I just use my family member's computer, with their permission.

My attempts are listed in chronological order and the ones I current use is noted with *

  • K9 Web Protection: works by using an application layer filtering, so the encrypted SSL connections are not filtered. There is a way to block it entirely, but it might make your email client and online banking unusable, and also most online transactions. Even though it enforces safe search, it only works on http connection. One could simple add one letter 's' and go on loose.

  • *OpenDNS - by itself, it is security by obscurity. Changing local DNS is so simple, but paired with DD-WRT, it is truly amazing.

  • Dans-guardian is pretty similar to K9 Web Protection, except if you are the root user of your computer, the restriction is solely controlled by your will-power. I have used it with gui on ubuntu, a linux OS. There is level of filtering you can adjust, but it did not filter SSL connection, if I remember correctly.

  • Firefox and Chrome extensions: yeah some are clever, but they can be easily disabled or moved. Also Internet Explorer is wide open, so blocking one web browser won't do the trick.

  • hosts file and focalfilter - this file is also security by obsecurity, it is not useful without a strong will power. But most importantly, it does not block SSL connections.

  • Qustodio - it is less featured than k9 and it gave me blue screen of death too often.

  • *DD-WRT - it gives you fine grain control over which keyword, website, and device (IP, MAC address) under Access Restriction. It also has the option to enforce the DNS server address.

  • *Iptables - this is the solution for SSL filtering and the good news is DD-WRT supports it. It seems complicated at first, but learning it will save you from a lot of headaches in the long run.

I was trying to block SSL connection by using a proxy server that has squidguard and dans-guardian. This is a method call Man-In-the-Middle (MITM) attack, which is more of a hack than a solution. This is also a method most organizations cannot implement as it violates the privacy of individuals. It is a fine solution for individuals, though. If I was succesful with this, I would have had the ultimate parental control that has the finest grain control over every aspect of network connectivity on the application layer, both http and https. Unfortunately, there was no iptables ported for my server, which is ARM architecture (e.g. your PC is X86, your android phone is ARM). iptables is necessary to make the latest squid work. Without it, there is no proxy server. Period. In a way, I was relieved that I did not go with squid. Because I would then have to block myself out of my server, which will now be a proxy server.

I used iptables before, but only for firewall. I do not know why this did not occur in my head. It seems as though not many people know about it. When I google about filtering SSL connections, most of the results (actually all I found) showed up saying that proxy server is the only way to block SSL connections. Well, this turned out to very wrong. After I went back and typed iptables and https filtering together, I finally found some good how-tos.

All links below will lead you to how-to-guides and other useful information.

OpenDNS Settings

After you sign-up, you can go the page called Web Content Filtering and check the boxes for the categories you would like to filter. I have the following checkmarks on:

Academic Fraud, Gambling, Humor, Lingerie/Bikini, P2P/File Sharing, Sexuality, Sports, Web Spam, Adult Themes, Anime/Manga/Webcomic, Games, Movies, Proxy/Anonymizer, Visual search engines, Adware, Dating, Nudity, Pornography

Now you can set the DNS address of your machines invidiaully. Not only that is a pain, but it is easy to bypass it just by changing it. You can restrict the access to this option via Group Policy Setting, but it is wortwhile to invest your time in DD-WRT enabled router, espeically so if want a privileged access to your machine. Yes you can just use your typical router to set the DNS address too, but once again, it can be bypassed. You really need a DD-WRT, a custom ROM for your router to make it work.

DD-WRT

After you have insalled DD-WRT on your router (the link will leads you to the how-to), go to your DD-WRT administrator's page by typing 192.168.1.1 in your web-browser. Change the static DNS under Basic Setup page. (Click on the first tab of Setup)

Static DNS1 208.67.220.220
Static DNS2 208.67.222.222
Static DNS3 208.67.220.220

Now under Services page, enable DNSMasq, disable Local DNS, enable No DNS Rebind and in the Addtional DNSMasq Options text box, put

strict-order

Now the DNS server is set for every client in the network and they cannot bypass just by changing on their machine. If you want to restrict certain machines but exclue some other machines, setting static IP address is the way to start. And it can be done on this page as long as you know the MAC address of your clients.

So in short, every machine has a unique MAC address, and whenever they connect to a router, they are assigned an IP address. The IP address assigned is random. But you can tell the router, "Hey, if you see this MAC address, give it this IP address". This is called static IP. It reserves an IP address so that only the machine with a certain MAC address gets that IP address.

Access Restriction

Now time for the real meat, Go to Access Restriction tab. You should be able to figure out without reading the manual. Here you can set the name of the policy, enabled/disabled them, set which clients (identified by either MAC address or IP address) are affected by the policy, and the time for which the policy will be in effective.

There are three things to watch out for:

  1. When you try to Edit List of clients, the new window that opens up may have boxes out of order. This was confusing for me as I was trying to type in the IP range of the clients, but maximizing the window will show the boxes in a proper order.
  2. The starting time has to be less than the ending time, so if you want to block from 10pm to 6 am, you have to create two restrictions that go from 10pm-12am (22:00-23:59), 12am to 6am(00:00-06:00).
  3. DD-WRT on my router had implicit restriction of 9 URL addresses and 8 keywords. Which means if they fill up I have to create another policy.

I have the following settings:

  1. *Morning Mon-Sat 0:00-12:00
  2. *Afternoon Mon-Sat 13:00-19:00
  3. *Evening Everyday 20:00-23:59 - above three are use to filter out entertainment / shopping / news by keyword.
  4. All Everyday 24Hours - this is used to filter out adult contents by keywords.
  5. Extra Everyday 24 - this is used to filter out Google plaintext image search.

* denotes that it only applies to specific computers as configured in the Edit List of clients

I have the following keywords to block google's video or image search:

site=imghp tbm=isch tbm=vid imgurl

Also I found it helpful to block following keywords:

sex girl xxx

I have more, but I would really like to keep this website rated G. I also tend to block out foreign websites by their country domain (e.g. co.jp), as they sometimes contain contents that are not well categorized under OpenDNS. Beware of just using it though, as the false-positive rate will rise. For example, when I used '.jp' as a keyboard, my router ended up blocking photos and even youtube! Images were blocked because of their extension (jpg, jpeg), but I do not know exactly why for youtube. (I block youtube anyway, because I end up wasting more time than learning there.)

Blocking Secure Connections

Now on to blocking SSH and SSL connections. Under Administration, change the password and give it your trusted family members. You may also disable SSH connection to the router as well on this page. Then go to Administration->Commands I have the following line to block SSL connections to certain websites. Notice the /25. This is called NetMask. Since I set my devices to IP addresses between '192.168.77.0 - 192.168.77.127' (Remember static IP address from before?), my filtering will only affect my devices.

for addr in facebook.com 31.13.65.0/24 31.13.66.0/24 31.13.67.0/24 66.220.152.19/27 66.220.152.130/27 67.215.65.130/27 173.252.112.23/27 pinterest.com 107.20.251.43 174.129.17.184 twitter.com tumblr.com quora.com slickdeals.net; do
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -m tcp -p tcp -s 192.168.77.1/25 -d "$addr" --dport 443 -j DROP
done

Quora and Slickdeals are blocked solely to keep me productive. Note that these may be accessible in plaintext, so it is important to block them by keywords, as mentioned in 'Access Restrction' section from before.

Blocking SSH Tunneling

To block ssh access, you need to block port 22, this dwarfs the SSH tunneling. If you do not know what SSH tunneling is, good! You can skip this section without worrying too much about it. You could possible block SSH port entirely, but that is up to you. I found myself this is indispensible for web hosting server management. An if I tried SSH tunneling on those web servers, I would have my contract revoked.

iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -m tcp -p tcp -s 192.168.77.1/25 -d [**address**] --dport 22 -j DROP

I could have successfully block OpenVPN based on the source port, which would have been easier for me to deal with. But It is very easy to redirect the source port on the client, so I had no choice but to block the destination port of VPN service provider.

iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -m tcp -p tcp -s 192.168.77.1/25 -d [**address**] --dport 80 -j DROP

Now click Save Firewall

Time restricted Google

Now that we know that the router resets itself at 12pm and 7pm, we can set rules at 1pm and 8pm so that the router starts blocking Google services. In another word, I have access to Google services between 12-1pm and 7-8pm.

/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/googleOn.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
for addr in youtube.com i1.ytimg.com google.com 74.125.20.0/24 173.194.79.0/24 173.125.239.0/24 190.93.245.76 74.125.239.0/24 74.125.224.0/24; do
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.0/24 -d "\$addr" -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j ACCEPT
done
EOF
'
chmod a+x /tmp/googleOn.sh

/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/googleOff.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
for addr in youtube.com i1.ytimg.com google.com 74.125.20.0/24 173.194.79.0/24 173.125.239.0/24 190.93.245.76 74.125.239.0/24 74.125.224.0/24; do
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.0/24 -d "\$addr" -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j DROP
done
for addr in gmail.com mail.google.com www.google.com; do
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.0/24 -d "\$addr" -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j ACCEPT

'
chmod a+x /tmp/googleOff.sh

/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/internetOff.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.0/24 -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j DROP
EOF
'
chmod a+x /tmp/internetOff.sh


/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/internetOn.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
iptables -t nat -D PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.0/24 -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j DROP
done
EOF
'

echo "00,01 12 * * * root /tmp/googleOn.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/googleOnNoon
echo "00,01 19 * * * root /tmp/googleOn.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/googleOnNight
echo "00 13 * * * root /tmp/googleOff.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/googleOffNoon
echo "00 20 * * * root /tmp/googleOff.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/googleOffNight

IPv6

I've noticed Google using IPv6 around the end of year 2013. The ip6tables is not available for all versions of DD-WRT, but thanksfulness, for now, if you use OpenDNS, all DNS translation will happen in IPv4.

Problems I faced and inconvenience chose to live with

  • Google Search and Services: I found out that Google no longer has the plain text search page. That is, www.google.com get redirected to https://www.google.com. To make things worse, all Google services IP addresses change. So it is not possible to block SSL connection solely based on IP addresses even with iptables. So I added 74.125.239.0/24 and 74.125.224.240/29 in the above code for this reason. This blocks everything between 74.125.239.0 to 74.125.239.255 and 74.125.224.0 to 74.125.224.7 and basically covers all Google services. So consequently, if I have not been clear, you will not be able to access any of Google Services while Google Search is blocked. Also if a website makes requests a javascript file from Google over SSL, the page will load forever on a web browser without rendering at all. This is because a web browser hangs when a request for a javascript file is not responded. Sometimes turning off javascript helps, sometimes it doesn't. So I chose to make 12-1pm and 7-8pm the most valuable time of my day, forcing myself to get things done when I feel most lazy.
  • Google AppEngine: Another problem I encountered with blocked Google was deploying a Google AppEngine Service. It was keep trying to authenticate via https://www.google.com and if I block even one of addresses that begin with 74.125.224.24X, it would throw an error. Oauth2 came to my rescue and it also saved me from typing password every time.

  • It is not possible to block Google Image Search while using Google (text) Search. The first ~30 search results are cached on www.google.com and it will be loaded without making any HTTP requests. Subsequent search results are looked up with these addresses:

    encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com encrypted-tbn1.gstatic.com encrypted-tbn2.gstatic.com encrypted-tbn3.gstatic.com

  • It is not possible to block just search (text, image). If you use even one Google service (with exception to Gmail), Google Search will be redirected to that IP address, and your Google Image Search will be open again.

  • In summary, you get either all of Google or none of Google. Hence the solution I posted above.

Bing Search in the time of desperation

Let me warn you, from my test of Bing, it was not even comparable to Google for search results. Any article that praises Bing at this moment down right goes as 'Microsoft-funded advertisement' in my book. You can compare the results yourself if your like with this website. But they do have plaintext search which I can filter. I just add the following URL to be blocked and I can have image-free search experience on Bing.

mm.bing.net
explicit.bing.net

Tools and Advice on Debugging

  • If you want to do the test of how easily loopholes are created, do it around 2AM, because IP address resolutions by Google server seem to be flexible around this time. But for other SSL connections, you could use ShowIP Firefox add-on to help you find the IP address.
  • If the application you use is not a web browser, you might have to do a little packet sniffing with wireshark to find out the IP address.

Turning off internet at predetermined time

I enjoy the quietness of midnights so I get tempted to work on my computer late. In order to prevent this, I block all internet access from the devices I use.

/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/internetOff.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -s 192.168.77.1/26 -j DROP
EOF
'
chmod a+x /tmp/internetOff.sh


/bin/sh -c 'cat > /tmp/internetOn.sh <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
iptables -t nat -D PREROUTING -s 192.168.77.1/26 -j DROP
done
EOF
'
chmod a+x /tmp/internetOn.sh


echo "00 00 * * * root /tmp/internetOff.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/internetOff
echo "00 07 * * * root /tmp/internetOn.sh" > /tmp/cron.d/internetOn

note that the mask is /26 instead of /25. This is allow some computers to not fall under the restriction, such as my server which does the off-site backup.

Restarting Router

I no longer need these code, but depending on your version of DD-WRT, your iptables may not work properly and you may need to reboot in order for the router to refresh some settings.

echo "startservice run_rc_shutdown; /sbin/reboot" > /tmp/restart_router
chmod a+x /tmp/restart_router
echo "00 12,19 * * * root /tmp/restart_router" > /tmp/cron.d/restartrouter

Conclusion

Thanks for reading this article and I hope it was helpful to your endeavors. If you have found a way to bypass this setup, please do not post it on comment section without a good remedy for the bypass. Also please support the developers if you end up using their software! Thanks!

If you found this guide really difficult to follow, it is not your fault. This is a difficult setup indeed. If you need a professional consulting, email me.

Other Software that people recommend, but I have not tried

Windows Live Family Safety - remote controlled access restriction DroidWall - App (GUI) for Android iptables. I have no smartphone yet, but this probably needs to be used with some parental control app for app restriction.

Paragon Hard Disk Manager did the job and it always have been in the top picks in the reviews that I wanted to try, so I finally had a winner.

The Most Disastrous Moment:

Computer backup is the insurance that you cannot outsource. So it is a hassle, no matter how automated it is, and it makes you become lazy about it. I have gotten lazy at point and I paid it dearly. I was trying to encrypt my external drive that has all my data without backing it up first. Since Truecrypt is a trusted software, I thought, it should be pretty safe as long as I am not doing anything. Well, not doing anything actually caused the problem. My laptop went to sleep mode while encryption was happening and truecrypt bricked my backup drive. And when your hard drive is half encrypted with a broken header, there is no way to recover it.

It is a pretty embarrassing story, but nonetheless I still get lazy about backup at times. Like when one software fails me and I have to switch over, or I move and the internet bandwidth is not good enough for off-site backup, or when my computer dies, etc, etc.

entry.content:
When I work, I work in a particular directory. And when I work, I also SSH with a particular username and a SSH key (to different machines). There are too many machines that I do not want to bother hard coding them to .ssh/config. Rather, I want something to change the default values for me. Wouldn't it be nice if ssh picked up different config files depending on where it was executed? Yes! It would allow me to easily manage different config files. Thankfully, Alec Thomas wrote ondir which was exactly I was looking for!

My idea is to always use an aliased ssh that takes in values for config file

alias ssh = `ssh -F $SSHCONFIG`

and let ondir change that variable SSHCONFIG.

Ondir Installation

So let's get started with the installation. Download the file from its main page and untar it. By default ondir installed on /bin, but I've decided to distinguish its installation local a bit.

curl http://swapoff.org/files/ondir/ondir-0.2.2.tar.gz | tar xz
cd ondir-0.2.2
sudo make PREFIX=/usr/local CONF=/usr/local/etc/ondirrc install

and you get the following output with a successful installation.

install -m 755 -d /usr/local/man/man1
install -m 644 ondir.1 /usr/local/man/man1
install -m 755 -d /usr/local/bin
install -m 755 ondir /usr/local/bin

You might need to re-login in order for ondir to take in effect.

Configuration

Typically, you would move the script.sh that comes in the tar package and run it in your bashrc, but I have the following function so that ls is executed for any cd. 

cd () {
    if [ $# -ne 0 ]
    then
            builtin cd "$*" && ls -hF --color
    else
            builtin cd ~
    fi
}

This function was in conflict with the script.sh of ondir, so I modified my code to incorporate it in my .bashrc (I source it from .zshrc, if you don't use zsh, you should)

which ondir &>/dev/null
if [ $? -eq 0 ]
then
    cd () {
        if [ $# -ne 0 ]
        then
            builtin cd "$*" && ls -hF --color && eval "`ondir \"$OLDPWD\" \"$PWD\"`"
        else
            builtin cd ~
        fi
    }
    pushd()
    {
        builtin pushd "$@" && eval "`ondir \"$OLDPWD\" \"$PWD\"`"
    }

    popd()
    {
        builtin popd "$@" && eval "`ondir \"$OLDPWD\" \"$PWD\"`"
    }
    SSHCONFIG="$HOME/.ssh/config"
    alias ssh='ssh -F $SSHCONFIG'
    # Run ondir on login
    eval "`ondir /`"
else
    cd () {
        if [ $# -ne 0 ]
        then
                builtin cd "$*" && ls -hF --color
        else
                builtin cd ~
        fi
    }
fi

Finally set the rule like the following in your .ondirrc

enter ~/main
    SSHCONFIG='$HOME/.ssh/company_config'
leave ~/main
    SSHCONFIG='$HOME/.ssh/config'

Other things to note

  • Notice the double quote for SSHCONFIG. Yes it is important, because it allows variable expansion.
  • space before and after = in bash disallow variable assignment.
  • environment variables that you set in your .bashrc file is not available in config files

for svm in svmips; do ssh nutanix@$svm "sudo scp -i ~/ssh_keys/nutanix -r ~/data/logs nutanix@10.3.1.242:/home/nutanix/public_html/jyoon/ENG-16049/triton/$svm" ; done for svm in svmips; do ssh nutanix@$svm "sudo scp -i ~/ssh_keys/nutanix -r ~/data/logs nutanix@10.3.1.242:/home/nutanix/public_html/jyoon/ENG-16049/nacho/$svm" ; done

entry.content:
Running OpenVPN with an alias

OpeVPN configuration comes in many different files: .crt, .key, .ovpn, .key. If you cd into the directory containing these files and sudo openvpn ***.ovpn, you are good to go. I wanted to set up an alias for this, omitting cd part. The trick is to add --config

sudo openvpn --config /path/to/myopen.ovpn

Let's say you have a password file associated with your OpenVpn connection. You would save your username and password to some file , say password.txt and store it along with other files. With the previous command, OpenVPN will complain and fail to find that file. You need to supply --cd flag in this case, which changes the initialization directory. 

sudo openvpn --config /path/to/myopen.ovpn --cd /path/to/

Just supplying --cd will not work for the first case. And here is my final script

sudo openvpn --config ~/Dropbox/server/openvpn/server.ovpn --cd ~/Dropbox/server/openvpn/ 2>&1 > /dev/null &

Windows Installation

On a Windows Machine, I was keep getting this message after installing OpenVPN GUI.

"All TAP-Win32 adapters on this system are currently in use."

Apparently despite this ensuring message: "Installation Package (Both 32-bit and 64-bit TAP driver included):" on the download site. The driver was not getting installed properly. After downloading the .exe from from OpenVpn Website, the drivers were properly installed and I was able to use OpenVPN GUI again.

tap vs tun

In the .ovpn file there is always a line that starts with dev, which is short for device. tap allows you to see the VPN while not losing your local IP subnet, effectively Ethernet becomes another ethernet switch for you. This introduces some overhead on the packet and you will also pick up the broadcasting messages. But using tun goes layer lower (layer 3) and routes all your traffic via VPN. If you are illegally downloading something, tun is not the way to go.

Password-less OpenVPN

Save a file with the following content

username
password

and save it with whatever you like (but the extension is important) in the same directory as your *.ovpn file. In the *.ovpn file, add a line:

auth-user-pass password.txt

This works in Linux, but not in Windows, because Windows client is not compiled with the right option by default. It is a good security measure considering the high percentage of Windows machines getting compromised.

Setting password on Key file with OpenVPN GUI

You have the option to enable password on *.key in addition to authentication. This can be done by right clicking the icon and clicking `Change Password, with OpenVPN GUI, once you set it, you cannot unset it. It will force you to type another password of at least 8 characters if you try to change it. You will either have to decrypt it on a Linux machine or just copy the saved copy of Key file over.

OpenVPN also does not allow tabbing through the prompt but it allows shift-tabbing.

DNS server not getting pushed on Windows

Just add this line to your *.ovpn file:

push "redirect-gateway"

or to push your own DNS server:

push "dhcp-option DNS 10.3.1.11"

Java versioning comes natural to you after you go through many installation process, but it is not clear right off the bat. - JDK is needed if you are a developer and compile Java program, JRE gives you the Java Virtual Machine so you can use the software. Most people just needs the latter. - If you install JDK, JRE is included ($JAVA_HOME/jre) so you do not need to install it separately. - OpenJDK and JavaJDK are different. The former is open source and rolls out features faster and the latter is proprietary by Oracle and is more stable. - IcedTea is a project name to keep OpenJDK free. - Since Oracle JDK is proprietary, it is not typicall included in the repository. You have to download it manually and link java hardlink to it. - You can have many versions installed, but you need to set them - Java Versions have two notation: 1.X for system and software documentation and just X for news, conversational language, and shorthand notation (package installer).

sudo update-alternatives --set java /opt/jdk1.7.0_40/bin/java

entry.content:
I guess the conventional way to control dotfile is using github. It is not a bad idea, but I stick with Dropbox for versioning. Yes, it is a version control for non-power user, but it is pretty handy to have your .vimrc every time you edit it. I typically document my dotfiles in the code and I have not found the commmit message to be useful for dotfiles.

Windows

Symlink dotfiles using Link Shell Extension. This allows me to edit dotfiles in either Dropbox or in my profile without worry about copying them over. I found hardlinks to not work as I expect from Unix environment. It is much simpler to use symlinks than trying to keep dotfiles in Dropbox and linking all your applications to read from them. Also expecting your dotfiles to exist in your home directory is a good practice in case you are in an environment where Dropbox is not available (ARM server comes to my mind).

Remote (Linux)

The only time I need to copy dotfiles to another server is when I log in to the server for the first time. I need to copy my public keys and dotifles and install some essential programs. First I save the host name in the .ssh/config file and then I do everything I need with the following function:

sshk() {
    ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub "$@"
    scp -q $HOME/Dropbox/dev/dotfiles/.??* "$@":
    ssh "$@" 'sudo apt-git install git vim; git clone https://github.com/robbyrussell/oh-my-zsh .oh-my-zsh; git clone https://github.com/gmarik/vundle.git ~/.vim/bundle/vundle; vim +BundleInstall +qall'
}

The last line clones Oh-My-Zsh and Vundle and then installs the plugins. Just save this in .bashrc and then run it with sshk hostName

It is exhilarating that you can feel home with just a few key strokes.

+ Dropbox

find $HOME/Dropbox/dev/dotfiles -maxdepth 1 -type f -name "\.*" -print0 | xargs -0 -I {} sh -c 'name=$(basename $0); if [ -f "$HOME/$name" ]; then rand=$(cat /dev/urandom | tr -dc 'a-zA-Z0-9' | fold -w 4 | head -1) mv "$HOME/$name" "$HOME/$name"."$rand"; fi; ln -s $0 $HOME' {}

ln -s $HOME/Dropbox/dev/dotfiles/vimperator $HOME/.vimperator

Use Ctrlp's g:ctrlp_switch_buffer instead of tab drop

tab drop allows you to switch to the tab with the specified name if it is already open. But it is very inefficiently done. It iterates through each tab until it finds the matching file. It is slow, and a custom function like 'switch to the last used tab' fails. ctrlp however has an option which fixes this. ctrp is a plugin that searches and opens recent files, files in the current directory, and files opened in the buffer. g:ctrlp_switch_buffer = 't'

to switch to the tab if it is already open. It is fast and works well.

gvim fails because it cannot create temporary files

as per dbeusee from github

This is not a permissions problem, and windows DOES in fact unset read-only. It's just a GUI bug that it thinks the bit is set. If you don't believe me, bring up the command prompt, cd to where the folder is, then do: dir /a:r. The folder you turned read-only off will not appear, because it really IS off.

The problem is really with the system() call. Just doing this from within vim will reproduce it:
:echo system("echo hi")

The problem is because some shell like cygwin shell is being used. I put these commands at the top of my _vimrc file to solve the problem:
set shell=cmd
set shellcmdflag=/c

This problem is solved now. I am not certain why this fixes it, because it seems like a race condition where the tmp file is created and closed before the process is done using it. The tmp file is in fact created successfully (I saw this with procmon), but it is closed/deleted before it's truely done with it.

entry.content:
Airline is the latest and hottest putting skins on statusline. There are at least a dozen of websites that explains how to install powerline fonts, but I found them confusing and felt like I was dealing with a bad customer service ("follow this link"). So here is how I got vim-airline to work with powerline fonts.

John Chain wrote about why airline is better. In short, vim-arline uses less code (1/12th of powerline, 1/3 of vim-powerline) and it is not python dependent. On a side note, I did not have to follow his advice on set lazydraw to get airline working in terminal.

My intention was to use Consolas font everywhere along with airline (vim, gvim, cygwin, windows, linux). I was successful, mostly. I still could not get powerline symbols to show up in cygwin terminal. Also git-gutter's color coding got lost whenever I saved a file, but I am hoping it will get straightened out over time.

Install vim-airline

I have tried Pathogen, NeoBundle, and Vundle. I recommend Vundle. I found it must faster in updating vim plugins.

# in .vimrc
Bundle 'blind/vim-airline'
# on commandline
:BundleInstall!

Font installation in Windows

I do not use any of these fonts, skip to Consolas Font section if you are a fan of that font.

Download the font:

git clone https://github.com/Lokaltog/powerline-fonts

If you right click them, there should be install option in the menu. Or you can drag it straight to Windows Fonts folder, or you really ought start using NexusFont to manage your font. Anyway, here are my opinions of the font.

Anonymous
DejaVuSansMono - 2nd best looking font
DroidSansMono - 2nd worst looking font
Inconsolata
InconsolataDz
MenloforPowerline - the worst looking font
MesloforPowerlineDZ
SourceCodePro 
UbuntuMono - the best looking font

All these fonts will be installed with 'Powerline' string as the suffix to their names. 'DejaVuSansMono Powerline's regular font (it shows up as Book in the font settings box) was not showing up as an option, forcing the user to choose 'Bold' or 'Bold Italic'. I was able to get the regular fonts back by deleting the 'DejaVuSansMono' font.

Font installation in Linux

Once again, skip to Consolas Font section if you are a fan of that font. I use Crunchbang Linux, so the installation details may differ. The installation details from Powerline Documentation says that 'there are two ways of installing the required fonts'. I think it is meant to says two STEPS, because they go together. Here is what I did.

cd ~/.fonts
git clone https://github.com/Lokaltog/powerline-fonts
wget https://github.com/Lokaltog/powerline/raw/develop/font/PowerlineSymbols.otf
wget https://github.com/Lokaltog/powerline/raw/develop/font/10-powerline-symbols.conf
# Merge the contents of 10-powerline-symbols.conf to ~/.fonts.conf
fc-cache -vf ~/.fonts

I say it must be two STEPS, because if you look at the content of '10-powerline-symbols.conf', it is patching 'Powerlinesymbols.otf' to Lokaltog's fonts and some of the popular linux fonts. The article does not make it clear that first way is a prerequisite for the second way, but it is the only explanation on the web I found, so I am very grateful. You can see the copy of my modified .fonts.conf here.

Consolas Font

Consolas is my favorite font, because it is a popular choice and I have no spine. I kid. Consolas font has design that is simple and clear. It is very comfortable to read. It is as if the font is trying its best to hide away complexity and let you focus on what you actually see. Euguneching was the original author of consolas-powerline-vim, a font patched up for powerline. When I tried it back in 2012, it did not work for me. So I gave up on using powerline altogether. That is how much consolas means to me. I even tried using fontpatcher on a copy of consolas font from Windows, but it still would not work. But I found Runsisi's version of font this time around and it worked well (Big dot next to trailing line notifcation in Windows gVim, does not show up though, sadly). I do not know what kind of magic he pulled off, but font designing is something that I will never do, so I am comfortable with not knowing the underlying details. And no, I will not bother fixing that one glyph in Windows gVim.

The step for Linux is similar to that of above:

cd ~/.fonts
git clone https://github.com/runsisi/consolas-font-for-powerline
fc-cache -vf ~/.fonts

Airline in Action

You need to set font encoing to 'utf-8' for glyphs to display properly. In gVim, that means setting set encoding=utf-8; In terminals, going to the preference and change the appropriate settings. For cygwin, it should be done already, but it can be changed in 'cygwin.bat' file in the cygwin installation directory. set LANG=en_US.UTF-8

Then I have the following lines in my .vimrc. This allows me to set the consolas font for Windows gVim and Linux gVim, respectively.

if has ('win32')
    set guifont=Powerline_Consolas:h9:cANSI
else
    set guifont=Powerline\ Consolas\ 10
endif

Airline's tabline is really well designed. It is turned off by default, but I really recommend the readers to use it. I used to have a problem where the tab separator would not show clearly in my Windows gVim. That problem is not gone thanks to Airline's tabline. Airline's themes come included in the git repo. The screenshots are also available online.. I think powerlineish theme looks the best.

let g:airline#extensions#tabline#enabled = 1
let g:airline_theme             = 'powerlineish'

Cygwin terminal

As I mentioned before, the symbols do not work. But it is very easy to turn on the non-glyph mode. Because glyph is turned off by default you just enable it with GUI mode.

if has ('win32unix') && !has('gui_running')
    let g:airline_powerline_fonts = 1
endif

Conclusion

Airline makes vim so beautiful. I get butterflies and chills as I stare into my vim now. I used to think that vim's vanilla version of statusline was enough since it shows all the information I need. Boy I was wrong. Color conveys information more quickly and efficiently than one may expect. I now believe that color encoding can be improved, always. Although color design is not a task I would pursue, it is something that I will keep tab on what pros are doing.

I am very reluctant to write about my vim configuration, because it changes so frequently. But I really using vim plugins by Shougo, I could not help writing something about it.

Neocomplcache

IMHO, the best autocompletion plugin around. I use the generic configuration as shown on the github page, with exception to two lines.

let g:neocomplcache_dictionary_filetype_lists = {
\ 'javascript' : expand('~/Dropbox/dev/dotfiles/others/javascript.dict') .','. expand('~/.vim/bundle/vim-node/dict/node.dict'),
\ }

let g:neosnippet#snippets_directory='~/.vim/bundle/vim-snippets/snippets, ~/Dropbox/dev/dotfiles/snippets'

The first line allows me to add dictionaries that are not part of the installation. One is linked to my Dropbox and the other to another vim plugin for javascript auto-completion. The second line is used to add other snippets. I just use Honza's snippets and my custom snippets, once again it is synced using Dropbox. It's very nice this way.

NeoSnippet

NeoSnippet shines over Honza's snippet because it displays the snippet signature in the autocompletion box. I add Honza's snippet to the mix anyway, because there are some that are not included in Neosnippet. I actually do not use snippet very often, but it is still a nice to have. Neosnippet works with Neocomplcache out of the box.

Neobundle

I only installed it because I thought it would simplify my vimshell installation. But I found it slower than Vundle, so I am going back.

Vimproc + Vimshell

Vimproc is kind of like an add-on for many of Shougo's newest inventions. I only installed it for vimshell and neobundle. It is a little tricky to install. Someone wrote that installing NeoBundle will compile Vimproc automatically. That was not the case for me in Windows. There are many options to install in Windows: mingw, msvs (MS Visual Studio), or cygwin. Of course, I went on with cygwin.

cd ~/.vim/bundle/vimproc/
make -f make_cygwin.mak

This will allow you to run Vimshell in Windows. But I still had trouble running Vimshell in gVim that I use, which is compiled to run on Windows natively using mingw-w64. It may seem reasonable to install mingw-w64 version of vimproc by installing mingw on cygwin. I found out that I did not have to do this. You can try if you'd like, but you still have to download this file a .dll file from this page to get the compilation going. If you use Windows gVim like I do, that file all you need. Just move it ~/.vim/bundle/vimproc/autoload and you are all set. Having cygiwn inside gVim is very nice. Here is a more detailed how-to for installation.

Watch Out for Capitalization

The capitalization matters when you specify the plugins to install. Shougo is capitalized.

entry.content:
In the beginning, I was looking for a solution where I could lookup markdown from vim with python or ruby, but then I found a vim script by Nate Silva that does this and it works well across many different platforms. I had to make minor changes.

Installation

Since I use pelican for blogging, I have python markdown installed, so I use that and make a symlink as markdown

pip install markdown
ln -s /usr/local/bin/markdown_py /usr/local/bin/markdown

then I just add the following scripts and I can get a markdown preview. Notice that I hardcoded BROWSER_COMMAND with firefox. This was because when I access files on a network drive, open sometimes did not work, failing to stat the file. 

function!PreviewMarkdown()
    " **************************************************************
    " Configurable settings

    let MARKDOWN_COMMAND = 'markdown'

    if has('win32')
        " note important extra pair of double-quotes
        let BROWSER_COMMAND = 'cmd.exe /c start '
    else
        let BROWSER_COMMAND = 'firefox'
    endif

    " End of configurable settings
    " **************************************************************

    silent update
    let output_name = tempname() . '.html'

    " Some Markdown implementations, especially the Python one,
    " work best with UTF-8. If our buffer is not in UTF-8, convert
    " it before running Markdown, then convert it back.
    let original_encoding = &fileencoding
    let original_bomb = &bomb
    if original_encoding != 'utf-8' || original_bomb == 1
        set nobomb
        set fileencoding=utf-8
        silent update
    endif

    " Write the HTML header. Do a CSS reset, followed by setting up
    " some basic styles from YUI, so the output looks nice.
    let file_header = ['<html>', '<head>',
        \ '<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8">',
        \ '<title>Markdown Preview</title>',
        \ '<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://yui.yahooapis.com/3.3.0/build/cssreset/reset-min.css">',
        \ '<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://yui.yahooapis.com/3.3.0/build/cssbase/base-min.css">',
        \ '<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://yui.yahooapis.com/3.3.0/build/cssfonts/fonts-min.css">',
        \ '<style>body{padding:20px;}div#container{background-color:#F2F2F2;padding:0 20px;margin:0px;border:solid #D0D0D0 1px;}</style>',
        \ '</head>', '<body>', '<div id="container">']
    call writefile(file_header, output_name)

    let md_command = '!' . MARKDOWN_COMMAND . ' "' . expand('%:p') . '" >> "' .
        \ output_name . '"'
    silent exec md_command

    if has('win32')
        let footer_name = tempname()
        call writefile(['</div></body></html>'], footer_name)
        silent exec '!type "' . footer_name . '" >> "' . output_name . '"'
        exec delete(footer_name)
    else
        silent exec '!echo "</div></body></html>" >> "' .
            \ output_name . '"'
    endif

    " If we changed the encoding, change it back.
    if original_encoding != 'utf-8' || original_bomb == 1
        if original_bomb == 1
            set bomb
        endif
        silent exec 'set fileencoding=' . original_encoding
        silent update
    endif

    silent exec '!' . BROWSER_COMMAND . ' "' . output_name . '"'

    exec input('Press ENTER to continue...')
    echo
    exec delete(output_name)
endfunction

" Map this feature to the key sequence ',p' (comma lowercase-p)
map <leader>mk :call PreviewMarkdown()<CR>

Usage

Just press mk (or the keys you have mapped) and see the browser with your markdown.

Inserting Links

Here are also commands I use to add links on my markdown. This makes things so much easier. 

" uses the clipboard register '+' (|quoteplus|) instead of register '*' for all operations except yank.  Yank shall copy the text into register '+' and also into '*' when "unnamed" is included.
set clipboard=unnamedplus 
" put a link to current word
nmap <leader>ml <Plug>Ysurroundiw]%a(<C-R>+)<Esc>
" put a link to current setence
nmap <leader>ms ^<C-v>$<Plug>VSurround]%a(<C-R>+)<Esc>
" put a link to current selection
vmap <leader>ml <Plug>VSurround]%a(<C-R>+)<Esc>

entry.content:
You can find keys in shell using .inputrc or .screenrc. In order to find the key codes to use, you can use either read command or press C-v and then enter in the key you like to map.

I have the following code in my .bashrc to figure out how keys are mapped. It excludes mapping with keywords which we are not interested with:

alias bindp='bind -p | grep -E -v "vi|bound| self|lowercase|argument"'

bound only shows up if the key is not bound self prints itself, so it tends to be important lowercase is for commands that is immune to shift key argument is for ???

Sometimes keys do not work

Binding special keys sometimes will not work, because the system grabs it before a terminal can. There is a work around so that the control is given up. In the following example, and are mapped to cycle through windows in screen. This works for xterm, unfortunately this does work not for gnome-terminals (including terminator) for the aforementioned reason.

Add the following lines to .Xresources:

*vt100.translations: #override \n\
    Ctrl ~Shift <Key>Tab: string(0x1b) string("[27;5;9~") \n \
    Ctrl Shift <Key>Tab: string(0x1b) string("[27;6;9~") \n

reload .Xresources:

xrdb ~/.Xresources

and add the following lines to .inputrc:

# Ctrl-Tab
bindkey "^[[27;5;9~" next

# Ctrl-Shift-Tab
bindkey "^[[27;6;9~" prev

to use if-statement in .inputrc, the syntax is as follows

$if mode=vi
$endif

entry.content:
I was quite happy with my Bash setup, until someone took my blindfold away and revealed to me the Fish shell. So I went on to check if there is something better. Well, now I know what zsh (1990) offers and that fish shell is the newest shell (2005). If you use Mac or Ubuntu, I encourage you to look at Hacker Codex, which has been the inspiration for this article.

I masochistically installed it on my Cygwin. Here is how it went. UPDATE: The conclusion is that fish is not mature enough for me to use it full time, but its features are very promising and I want people to give it a try... maybe go further than where I have been.

Installation

cd /opt
git clone https://github.com/fish-shell/fish-shell/
automake && ./config
vim fallback.h
# remove the following line start on line 89

##ifdef TPARM_SOLARIS_KLUDGE

#/**
#   Solaris tparm has a set fixed of paramters in it's curses implementation,
#   work around this here.
#*/

##define tparm tparm_solaris_kludge
#char *tparm_solaris_kludge(char *str, ...);

finally install

make && make install

Setup "fish.config" == ".bashrc"

I changed my Cygwin.bat to be:

@echo off

C:
chdir C:\cygwin\usr\local\bin
fish

and also edit /etc/passwd and change my shell to /usr/local/bin/fish

Then I opened my mintty console. The color of vim looks aweful in Cygwin or cmd.exe because I do not think they support 256 color. Well I get the following message:

fish: Could not connect to universal variable server, already tried manual restart (or no command supplied). You will not be able to share variable values between fish sessions. Is fish properly installed?
Welcome to fish, the friendly interactive shell
Type help for instructions on how to use fish

Well looking at the document, there is daemon called fishd that is supposed to do its job. Uh... it is not in my PATH? There is one in /opt/fish-shell just symlink it. Then you need to make it run when you launch your shell. I have the following lines in my `~/.config/fish/config.fish

set PATH /usr/local/bin $PATH
set PATH /usr/sbin $PATH
fishd
set -g BROWSER firefox.exe
cd

This is the very minimum, I think, to get fish working properly. While getting fish to work with screen, I kept on getting this message again. Anyway, I had to replace alias to function when I ported my '.bashrc' so that I wouldn't get any warning. I accomplished this with the following vim command:

'<,'>s/alias \(\w\{-}\)='\(.*\)'/function \1\r\t\2\rend\r/g

My home directory was set to System32, despite setting the home directory on /etc/passwd. My guess is that it is because fish shell is called by cmd.exe, because nothing showed up on a profile dump. Well, hence cd in the last code snippet.

Fixing LS

The problem is mentioned in the github. In short you get error messages. So I just gutted (commented) the following lines from '/usr/local/share/fish/functions/ls.fish'

if not set -q LS_COLORS
    if type -f dircolors >/dev/null
        eval (dircolors -c)
    end
end

and it went away. I believe the problem is with discolor, which I do not think is needed.

On a side note, make sure you do not define function ls anywhere. It thinks it is going to get into an infinite loop. To me, this does not seem very robust, as alias is a syntactic sugar for function. I had to modify my ls to exlucde ntuser files which clutters up home directory unnecessarily whenever I ls oh and I had to escape the kleene star *

set param $param --indicator-style=classify --time-style=iso --ignore=ntuser\*

Vim

the directory in PATH is in different order than Cygwin, so I had to add the following line to make sure that gVim is not invoked instead of vim. Otherwise, vim will hang because the shell does not know what to do with the GUI version.

function vim
    /bin/vim $argv
end

GNU Screen

I added the following line so that fish will run whenever I create a new window

defshell /usr/local/bin/fish

Syntax

Okay, consult the man page with help, but just know that the command substitution works with just parenthesis. In another word without '$'

Bunch of message with x86

You will get the following message whenever you try to auto-complete a command. 

fish: The file 'x86' is not executable by this user
in command substitution
    called on standard input,

The problem is hard coded in the source code and directories with parenthesis are not being parsed correctly. I posted the issue on Github.

Other problems

Fish does not seem to be snappy at times like Bash. Maybe it has to do with "spawning new thread problem" of Cygwin and it would probably has to do with caching too. For me, hanging shell is a deal breaker. The very reason why I go command line is the speed. Yes it is sad, but I just cannot give up my workflow.
